NewsDetail.BodyCopy:
Last year while reading in the Book of Mormon, I came to understand that the Lord used Learning Model principles to teach the Brother of Jared.   The more I readand study, the more I become convinced that the Lord teaches all His children using the principles promoted in the Learning Model.  We can learn much from the dialogue the Brother of Jared had with the Lord about how we ought to teach the students placed in our care.

 

Different Questions Call for Different Answers

The Brother of Jared was given an assignment from his “Teacher” to build some barges.   Along with this assignment the Lord gave the directions needed to build the barges and reasons for building them.  Put simply, the Lord told the Brother of Jared to “Go to work and build” (Ether 2:16).   During the process of constructing the barges, three serious questions arose.  How will we breathe?  How will we steer?  Must we journey in darkness?  Seeking solutions, the Brother of Jared inquired of the Lord, and the Lord answered.  But He responded differently to each question.  Likewise, we must respond differently to different types of questions asked by our students.  

Responding to Air Questions

The Brother of Jared’s first question was a simple question about air.  Consistent with the level of the question, the Lord responded with a simple solution—cut holes in the top and the bottom.  But why did the Lord respond with such a direct answer?  I believe that it was because He knew that the Brother of Jared would not be able to find an appropriate solution alone.  Air is a necessity, a matter of survival.  Without air we perish.   Just like the solution to the air problem, solutions to many student questions can be provided through direct and simple answers.  Such answers are appropriate when a student asks a vital question that he/she doesn’t have the knowledge or experience to answer alone.  To survive, that student needs a direct, simple answer.  We can’t let him/her perish for lack of air!

 

Responding to Steering Questions

Next, the Brother of Jared inquired as to how to steer the barges.  Steering questions are about direction.  How will we navigate our barges without crashing or getting lost?  Winds, like new information, principles, or instructions, seem to blow from all directions at once.  Students need to feel safe.  The Brother of Jared needed to believe that the winds, the rains and the floods had been “sent forth” by the Lord (see Ether 2:24-25) before he could summon the courage to sail into unknown waters.  Likewise, we need to provide students with safe environments where they can contribute, participate in discussions, and try out new ideas.  Without proper steering, our students will be “swallowed up in the depths of the sea” (Ether 2:25).

 

Responding to Light Questions

The last question that the Brother of Jared asked concerned light.  He asked the Lord, must we cross the great waters in darkness?  It seems like a reasonable question, but this time the Lord didn’t provide an answer.  Instead, he answered the question with a question.  “What will ye that I should prepare for you that ye may have light when ye are swallowed up in the depths of the sea?”  (Ether 2:25)  This response wasn’t like the plain and direct answers that followed the steering and air inquiries.  The Lord essentially said to the Brother of Jared, “You have a problem.  What are you going to do about it?” (see Ether 2:25). 

 

In response to this challenge, the Brother of Jared acted for himself.  He came up with a plan, climbed a mountain, and then melted, shaped, and polished sixteen small stones.  After doing all he could do to solve the problem, the Brother of Jared went to the Lord and said something like this: “Now don’t be angry with me, but I know you have the ability to touch these stones and make them glow.  Please touch them.”  By presenting those little stones to the Lord, the Brother of Jared exercised his faith to bring to pass “much righteousness” (D&C 58:27). 

 

We as teachers must learn to recognize Light questions.  Light questions are opportunities for students to take responsibility for their learning.  Light comes after a student makes the effort to apply what he has learned.  Students are blessed to receive revelation in response to their Light questions but they need to propose their own solutions first.  I sometimes tell my students, “That is a Light question.  What are you going to do about it?”  As they struggle to find meaningful solutions to their questions, their vision becomes clearer.  They have to stretch to apply new knowledge and in the process they learn how to govern themselves.  It is in this struggle that they find answers to Light questions. 

 

A New World

The Brother of Jared’s world changed as light led to vision.  He comprehended more than he ever knew was possible.  It was a new world; one which the Brother of Jared had never seen before or even knew existed.   We all walk in darkness until we develop enough faith to walk in the light.  Our students must learn that lesson.  It is in the struggle to polish the stones that we develop the faith that allows the Lord to touch our small offering.  We must remember that there is a great difference between air, steering and light questions.  There should be great differences in our answers.
